links.tooltip: See inventory files for all clusters and environments

options.content:
- [Ansible playbooks](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/db-migration/-/tree/master/pg-upgrade-logical)
- [Inventory in Ansible](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/db-migration/-/tree/master/pg-upgrade-logical/inventory)
- [CR template](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/db-migration/-/blob/master/.gitlab/issue_templates/pg14_upgrade.md) (individual CRs are to be located at ops.gitlab.net)
- [Diagram illustrating the process](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/db-migration/-/blob/master/.gitlab/issue_templates/pg14_upgrade.md#high-level-overview)
üèπ Source cluster: PG12, Ubuntu 20.04 (prefixes contain hard-coded `v12` and/or `2004`)

panels.title: üèπ üèÉüèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Physical replication lag on source standbys, in seconds
üéØ üèÉüèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Physical replication lag on target standbys, in seconds
üèπ üèÉüèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Physical replication lag on source standbys, in bytes
üéØ üèÉüèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Physical replication lag on target standbys, in bytes

targets.expr:
sum(irate(pg_stat_user_tables_n_tup_ins{env="$env", fqdn=~"patroni-${cluster}-v14-.*"}[1m])
+
irate(pg_stat_user_tables_n_tup_del{env="$env", fqdn=~"patroni-${cluster}-v14-.*"}[1m])
+
irate(pg_stat_user_tables_n_tup_upd{env="$env", fqdn=~"patroni-${cluster}-v14-.*"}[1m])) by (instance)
and on(instance) pg_replication_is_replica==0

panels.title: Tuple stats: ins/upd/del, index fetches, seq reads
Backups (daily full backups and continuous WAL archiving)

panels.description: IMPORTANT: look at least 2 day interval. If you see 2 rows, then a gap, then another 2 rows, then you have a recent (< 24 hours) successful backup. The gap is the period of time when the backups were executing. You can use a timestamp converter https://www.epochconverter.com/ to convert the timestamps into human-readable date/time if you want to check when the backup finished.

targets.expr: gitlab_job_success_timestamp_seconds{resource="walg-basebackup", env="$env", type=~"${env}-patroni-${cluster}-(pg12|2004).*"} > gitlab_job_start_timestamp_seconds{resource="walg-basebackup", env="$env", type=~"${env}-patroni-${cluster}-(pg12|2004).*"} and on (resource, env, type) gitlab_job_failed == 0

panels.title: üèπ Source full backups (chat at least 2 days)

panels.description: IMPORTANT: look at least 2 day interval. If you see 2 rows, then a gap, then another 2 rows, then you have a recent (< 24 hours) successful backup. The gap is the period of time when the backups were executing. You can use a timestamp converter https://www.epochconverter.com/ to convert the timestamps into human-readable date/time if you want to check when the backup finished.

targets.expr: gitlab_job_success_timestamp_seconds{resource="walg-basebackup", env="$env", type=~"${env}-patroni-${cluster}-(v14).*"} > gitlab_job_start_timestamp_seconds{resource="walg-basebackup", env="$env", type=~"${env}-patroni-${cluster}-(v14).*"} and on (resource, env, type) gitlab_job_failed == 0

panels.title: üéØ  Target full backups (chat at least 2 days)

panels.description: you should be able to see an increase of the value every time the backup starts (around midnight). If the last increase was more than 24 hours ago then it means that the last backup hasn't started as it should have, and you'll need to investigate why the job failed to start.
panels.title: üèπ Source full backup start time

panels.description: you should be able to see an increase of the value every time the backup starts (around midnight). If the last increase was more than 24 hours ago then it means that the last backup hasn't started as it should have, and you'll need to investigate why the job failed to start.
panels.title: üéØ  Target full backup start time

panels.description:
If the value is > 0 for any time in the past 24 hours, then you'll need to investigate why the job failed.


The backup job is triggered by crond (user: gitlab-psql) and any replica is eligible to run the job but it only runs on the one that acquires the consul lock.
panels.title: üèπ Source full backup failures ‚ùå

panels.description:
If the value is > 0 for any time in the past 24 hours, then you'll need to investigate why the job failed.


The backup job is triggered by crond (user: gitlab-psql) and any replica is eligible to run the job but it only runs on the one that acquires the consul lock.
panels.title: üéØ  Target full backup failures ‚ùå

title: Postgres 14 upgrade using logical (all envs, all clusters)   (Nik, tmp)
